title: 105_hr1402
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Commission on Probabilistic Methods Act". The Congress recognizes the wide applicability of probabilistic methods in improving efficiency and reducing overdesign in government programs. Integrating these methods into business practices has saved billions of dollars for companies. Federal use of probabilistic methods lags behind industry, but they hold promise for better understanding safety and environmental risks. Implementing probabilistic methods in federally funded design efforts could lead to cost reductions and better product specifications. The Department of Transportation could benefit from using probabilistic methods to quantify uncertainties and improve reliability. The Department of Transportation could benefit from using probabilistic methods to quantify uncertainties and improve reliability in transportation systems, which could also benefit other Federal agencies. The Administrator of the Research and Special Programs Administration of the Department of Transportation will establish the Commission on Probabilistic Methods to improve reliability in transportation systems. The Commission on Probabilistic Methods will identify, assess, evaluate, establish models, recommend guidelines, and set reliability levels to improve reliability in transportation systems and increase public safety. The Commission on Probabilistic Methods will recommend guidelines for safety tests, database creation, technology transfer, legal barriers, program use, institutionalization of values, and pilot projects for the Department of Transportation. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 19 members, including a chairperson with engineering expertise, representatives from higher education, government, industry, labor, environmental community, and public interest. Additionally, there will be representatives from the Department of Defense, Department of Commerce, and National Institutes of Health. Members serve for the life of the Commission. The Commission consists of 19 members appointed by various entities, serving for life without pay. Members receive travel expenses and must constitute a quorum of 10 for hearings. The initial meeting must occur within 180 days, with an agenda submitted within 6 months. The Department of Transportation will provide administrative support to the Commission for its duties. The Commission can hire experts and consultants as needed. It can also obtain official data from government agencies and use the United States mails. The Commission is required to submit reports. SEC. 7. REPORTS.

The Commission must submit an interim report to the Administrator within 2 years of its initial meeting and a final report within 36 months. The final report will include findings, conclusions, and recommendations.

SEC. 8. TERMINATION.

The Commission will end 10 days after submitting the final report, and the Federal Advisory Committee Act's termination rules do not apply.

SEC. 9. BUDGET ACT COMPLIANCE.

Spending authority authorized by this Act is only effective as provided in appropriation Acts.
